abstract.p: Illuminated 15th century prayer book made in Ferrara, Italy, is focus of exhibition set for Getty Center, Los Angeles; 15-day celebration of Irish arts is set for Kennedy Center for Performing Arts, Washington; American Ballet Theater to open 60th season with gala performance; three lower-Manhattan concerts hosted by Ivy Austin will celebrate songs from Shubert theaters to mark Shubert Organization's centennial; photos (M)

block.p: On the occasion of the marriage of the Renaissance aristocrats Andrea Gualengo and Orsina d'Este in 1469, Taddeo Crivelli and Guglielmo Giraldi, the foremost manuscript illustrators of Ferrara, produced a prayer book. Sometimes whimsical, sometimes pious and moving, its illuminations on pages measuring only 4 1/4 by 3 1/8 inches combine the spirituality of the Middle Ages with Renaissance naturalism. Regarded as the greatest Italian manuscript in the J. Paul Getty Collection, the Gualenghi-d'Este Hours goes on view tomorrow at the Getty Center in Los Angeles as the focus of a new exhibition. Through July 30, ''The Gualenghi-d'Este Hours: Art and Devotion in Renaissance Ferrara'' includes related objects from the British Museum in London, the National Gallery in Washington and the Museo Civico of the Palazzo Schifanoia in Ferrara, Italy. Information: (310) 440-7300.

On the occasion of the marriage of the Renaissance aristocrats Andrea Gualengo and Orsina d'Este in 1469, Taddeo Crivelli and Guglielmo Giraldi, the foremost manuscript illustrators of Ferrara, produced a prayer book. Sometimes whimsical, sometimes pious and moving, its illuminations on pages measuring only 4 1/4 by 3 1/8 inches combine the spirituality of the Middle Ages with Renaissance naturalism. Regarded as the greatest Italian manuscript in the J. Paul Getty Collection, the Gualenghi-d'Este Hours goes on view tomorrow at the Getty Center in Los Angeles as the focus of a new exhibition. Through July 30, ''The Gualenghi-d'Este Hours: Art and Devotion in Renaissance Ferrara'' includes related objects from the British Museum in London, the National Gallery in Washington and the Museo Civico of the Palazzo Schifanoia in Ferrara, Italy. Information: (310) 440-7300.

Who says the celebration of things Irish must be confined to St. Patrick's Day? Certainly not the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, where a 15-day festival of Irish arts begins on Saturday night at 8. ''Island: Arts From Ireland'' encompasses dance, music, film, drama, poetry, visual arts and readings. The gala opening concert, with the author Frank McCourt as host, focuses on the links among the music of Ireland, Scotland and the United States from the mid-19th century to the present. Featured performers include Mary Black, Elvis Costello, Emmylou Harris, Maighread and Triona Ni Dhomhnail, Ricky Skaggs and members of the Riverdance company. Information: (800) 444-1324.

With Vice President and Mrs. Gore as honorary chairman and chairwoman, a gala performance at the Metropolitan Opera House at 6:30 tonight opens the 60th season of American Ballet Theater. The program will feature the New York premiere of Twyla Tharp's ''Variations on a Theme by Haydn'' and excerpts from the season's full-length ballets and repertory favorites like ''Le Corsaire,'' ''Theme and Variations'' and Kevin McKenzie's production of ''Swan Lake.'' Information: (212) 362-6000.

On any list of terrific songs, ''Swanee,'' ''Toot, Toot, Tootsie, Goodbye'' and ''Lullaby of Broadway'' can claim space. Songs like these can be heard in the Winter Garden at the World Financial Center on three consecutive Mondays beginning at 6:30 tonight. The event, with Ivy Austin as the host and a performer, is ''Songs From Shubert Stages: A Centennial Celebration of the Shubert Organization.'' The commemoration of music heard at Shubert theaters on Broadway and across the country begins with a program featuring Christine Ebersole and Richard Muenz. Information: (212) 945-0505.
